abstract: Federal appeals court in San Francisco rejects arguments made by Mohamed Mohamud, Somali-American convicted in 2013 of trying to detonate bomb in Portland, Ore, that FBI had unconstitutionally intercepted his emails without warrant; ruling is important because it upheld government's use of emails gathered without warrant under FISA Amendments Act of 2008.

keywords.value: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
keywords.name: subject

lead_paragraph: A panel of three federal judges rejected the argument that the F.B.I. had entrapped Mohamed Mohamud and unconstitutionally intercepted his emails without a warrant.
snippet: A panel of three federal judges rejected the argument that the F.B.I. had entrapped Mohamed Mohamud and unconstitutionally intercepted his emails without a warrant....

headline.main: Terrorism Conviction of a Wiretapped American Is Upheld on Appeal
headline.print_headline: Panel Backs Warrantless Collection of Email
